title.narrative: Journalistic investigation on Organized Crime in Central America and Colombia
Journalistisk utredning om organiserad brottslighet i Centralamerika & Colombia

description.narrative:
InSight Crime Incoporated är en organisation med huvudkontor i USA och Colombia, och som ägnar sig åt att studera organiserad brottslighet som ett hot mot nationell och medborgerlig säkerhet i Latinamerika och Karibien.
InSight Crime har inkommit med ett projektförslag till Sveriges ambassader i Bogotá och Guatemala City med titeln "Organised Crime and Corruption, Gender and the Search for Peace in Central America, Colombia and Venezuela" om ett totalt belopp på USD 773 428, att finansieras via båda ambassaders respektive landstrategier.
Målet med programmet är att framställa minst 12 utredningar i följande frågor: 1) Hur den moderna staten har förvrängts av kriminella intressen i Centralamerika, Colombia och Venezuela; 2) Hur genus utvecklas i vissa avseenden inom kriminella organisationer, men till stor del är statisk i andra, särskilt vad avser uppbyggnad och utveckling av gatu- och fängelsegäng; 3) Hur regeringar skapar och undergräver fredsprocesser och vapenvilor, och vilka konsekvenser denna politik har.

InSight Crime Incoporated, a non-profit organization duly established in Washington DC, and with an office in Colombia, is dedicated to the study of organized crime as a threat to national and citizen security in Latin America and the Caribbean.
Insight Crime submitted to the Embassies of Sweden in Bogotá and Guatemala City a proposal titled “Organized Crime and Corruption, Gender, and the Search for Peace in Central America, Colombia and Venezuela” for a total amount of USD 773 428 to be funded by the country strategies of both embassies.
The objective of the programme is to produce at least 12 investigations, on the following matters: 1) how the modern State has been distorted by criminal interests in Central America, Colombia and Venezuela; 2) how the role of gender is evolving in some respects inside criminal organizations, but largely static in others, especially as it relates the construction and development of street and prison gangs; 3) how governments forge and undermine peace processes and truces, and what the consequences of these policies are.

InSight Crime will produce between twelve (12) and fifteen (15) investigative reports on aspects of organized crime in the Northern Triangle, Nicaragua, Colombia and Venezuela. These investigations will be published over a three-year period and be disseminated via InSight Crime’s internet platform, as well as through local and international media, in an effort to provide understanding and provoke debate about systemic and cultural challenges in these countries as it relates to these issues.

description.narrative: The contribution has only been in place for three months at the time of writing. As a result, no results are reported. COVID-19 has been very challenging for InSight Crime during the pre-investigation phase contemplated in the agreement (months 1-3). Although InSight Crime has proxies and contacts in the field, the very human aspect of journalism has been impacted by the pandemic and led the partner to have to resort to creative or alternative ways in which to carry out its investigations from home. For example, InSight Crime has decided that rather than focusing on a few specific gender investigations, it will carry out more gender-related investigations throughout the duration of the contribution so that gender-related stories more easily accessible to the researchers’ homes can also be explored. InSight Crime is moving forward in implementing the gender perspective in house. The first internal gender workshop for gender mainstreaming, and how to incorporate the gender perspective in reporting is currently in process. It is expected that the full integration of this perspective shall take many years to be fully adopted, however, the organization is already putting things in motion for this change to take place.
